title: Matildas captain Sam Kerr suffers  devastating  ACL injury six months out from Paris Olympics
body_text:
Matildas captain Sam Kerr suffers 'devastating' ACL injury six months out from Paris Olympics
Matildas captain Sam Kerr has ruptured an anterior cruciate ligament (ACL) while in a mid-season training camp in Morocco with Chelsea and is unlikely to play at the Paris Olympics if Australia earns qualification.
Key points:
- The Matildas coach described the news as "devastating" for his squad
- Kerr will miss the second half of Chelsea's WSL season
- The Matildas are expected to qualify for the Olympics
Matildas coach Tony Gustavsson said Kerr's injury was a massive hit to his team's hopes of making the Paris Games.
"Considering how hard Sam has worked over the past six months to return to play, this news is a devastating blow for everyone," Gustavsson said in a statement.
"With her ability to lead by example, Sam's guidance and influence on the team is significant and, as a result, this will be an incredible loss for the national team.
"Our focus now is on ensuring she has all the support she wants and needs to navigate recovery and rehab."
Kerr has already been ruled out of the second half of Chelsea's Women's Super League (WSL) and European Champions League campaigns, and Australia's AFC Women's Olympic qualifiers against Uzbekistan next month.
The Matildas only need to win the two-leg tie against Uzbekistan, ranked 47th in the world, to qualify for Paris.
Where is your ACL?
The ACL runs diagonally in the middle of the knee. It connects the thigh bone (femur) to the shin bone (tibia) and stabilises the knee.
What is an ACL injury?
ACL injuries commonly occur during sports that involve sudden stopping, changes in direction and twisting — such as football and basketball.
When ruptured, many people hear a pop or feel a "popping" sensation in the knee. They may also experience swelling, severe pain and a feeling of instability, as if the knee is "giving way".
How long does it take to recover from a ruptured ACL?
It is rare for a player to return from an ACL injury with less than nine months of rehabilitation and it often takes longer.
Chelsea said she would be "assessed by a specialist in the coming days and then begin her rehabilitation with the club's medical team".
The football tournament at the Olympics takes place from July 24 to August 10, which is in roughly six months.
Kerr's Matildas teammate Steph Catley was among those to offer her emotional support.
"Here with you every step," wrote Catley on X (formerly Twitter).
Matildas midfielder Caitlin Foord also expressed her disappointment.
"We've got you," Foord wrote.
Another member of the Matildas' World Cup squad, Emily van Egmond, also reached out to Kerr.
"With you every step of the way always," she wrote.
Matildas great Melissa Barbieri said no timeline could be put on when Kerr would return to the playing field.
"It's about ticking the boxes and making sure you get a strong recovery," she said.
"It can be as little as six months but as long as 18, depending on what can go right and what can go wrong."
Kerr's recent injury troubles
The ruptured ACL adds to an injury-marred past six months for Kerr.
She sat out the group stage of the Matildas' World Cup campaign because of a calf injury in her left leg.
Despite fears she would not take the field at all during the tournament hosted by Australia and New Zealand, Kerr returned for the knockout rounds.
She came off the bench against Denmark and France, before starting in the 3-1 semifinal loss to England in which she scored a spectacular goal for the Matildas.
She later revealed she sustained a second calf injury in her right leg in the Matildas' 2-0 loss to Sweden in the third-place play-off.
Kerr, runner-up to Spain's Aitana Bonmatí at the Ballon d'Or awards last year, is Australia's record goal-scorer with 69 in 128 matches.
She has scored 99 goals in 128 matches for the club, winning the WSL Golden Boot twice, four league titles and three FA Cups.
The 30-year-old was recently joined in London by her partner, American player Kristie Mewis, who joined WSL rivals West Ham United.
Kerr is the latest high-profile player to suffer an ACL injury, which seems more prevalent in the women's game and is belatedly the subject of research into why this is the case.
Ellie Carpenter, Kyah Simon, Chloe Logarzo and Elise Kellond-Knight are among Australian players to have had ACL injuries in recent years.
England's Beth Mead and Leah Williamson, Vivianne Miedema of the Netherlands and France's Marie-Antoinette Katoto were among a string of stars to miss the World Cup due to ACL injuries.
AAP/ABC
